an3.95:1.3.pli: Aggavatī parisā, vaggā parisā, samaggā parisā.
an3.95:1.3.eng: An assembly of the best, a divided assembly, and a harmonious assembly.

an3.95:2.1.eng: And what is an assembly of the best?

an3.95:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yassaṃ parisāyaṃ therā bhikkhū na bāhulikā honti na sāthalikā, okkamane nikkhittadhurā paviveke pubbaṅgamā, vīriyaṃ ārabhanti appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya, tesaṃ pacchimā janatā diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjati.
an3.95:2.2.eng: An assembly where the senior mendicants are not indulgent or slack, nor are they backsliders. Instead, they take the lead in seclusion, rousing energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized. And those who come afterwards follow their example.

an3.95:2.3.pli: Sāpi hoti na bāhulikā na sāthalikā okkamane nikkhittadhurā paviveke pubbaṅgamā, vīriyaṃ ārabhati appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an3.95:2.3.eng: They too are not indulgent or slack, nor are they backsliders. Instead, they take the lead in seclusion, rousing energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

an3.95:2.4.eng: This is called an assembly of the best.

an3.95:3.1.eng: And what is a divided assembly?

an3.95:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yassaṃ parisāyaṃ bhikkhū bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṃ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharanti, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, vaggā parisā.
an3.95:3.2.eng: An assembly where the mendicants fight, quarrel, and dispute, continually wounding each other with barbed words. This is called a divided assembly.

an3.95:4.1.eng: And what is a harmonious assembly?

an3.95:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yassaṃ parisāyaṃ bhikkhū samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṃ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharanti, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, samaggā parisā.
an3.95:4.2.eng: An assembly where the mendicants live in harmony, appreciating each other, without dispute, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes. This is called a harmonious assembly.

an3.95:5.1.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye bhikkhū samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṃ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharanti, bahuṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhū tasmiṃ samaye puññaṃ pasavanti.
an3.95:5.1.eng: When the mendicants live in harmony like this, they brim with much merit.

an3.95:5.2.pli: Brahmaṃ, bhikkhave, vihāraṃ tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhū viharanti, yadidaṃ muditāya cetovimuttiyā.
an3.95:5.2.eng: At that time the mendicants live in a divine dwelling, that is, the heart’s release by rejoicing.

an3.95:5.3.pli: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vediyati, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
an3.95:5.3.eng: When they’re joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss. And when they’re blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

an3.95:6.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, uparipabbate thullaphusitake deve vassante taṃ udakaṃ yathāninnaṃ pavattamānaṃ pabbatakandarapadarasākhā paripūreti, pabbatakandarapadarasākhā paripūrā kusobbhe paripūrenti, kusobbhā paripūrā mahāsobbhe paripūrenti, mahāsobbhā paripūrā kunnadiyo paripūrenti, kunnadiyo paripūrā mahānadiyo paripūrenti, mahānadiyo paripūrā samuddaṃ paripūrenti.
an3.95:6.1.eng: It’s like when the heavens rain heavily on a mountain top, and the water flows downhill to fill the hollows, crevices, and creeks. As they become full, they fill up the pools. The pools fill up the lakes, the lakes fill up the streams, and the streams fill up the rivers. And as the rivers become full, they fill up the ocean.

an3.95:7.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, yasmiṃ samaye bhikkhū samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṃ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharanti, bahuṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhū tasmiṃ samaye puññaṃ pasavanti.
an3.95:7.1.eng: In the same way, when the mendicants are in harmony, appreciating each other, without dispute, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes, they create much merit.

an3.95:7.2.pli: Brahmaṃ, bhikkhave, vihāraṃ tasmiṃ samaye bhikkhū viharanti, yadidaṃ muditāya cetovimuttiyā.
an3.95:7.2.eng: At that time the mendicants live in a divine dwelling, that is, the heart’s release by rejoicing.

an3.95:7.3.pli: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vediyati, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
an3.95:7.3.eng: When they’re joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss. And when they’re blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

an3.96:1.1.pli: “Tīhi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato rañño bhadro assājānīyo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅganteva saṅkhyaṃ gacchati.
an3.96:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a fine royal thoroughbred with three factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and reckoned as a factor of kingship.

an3.96:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño bhadro assājānīyo vaṇṇasampanno ca hoti balasampanno ca javasampanno ca.
an3.96:1.3.eng: It’s when a fine royal thoroughbred is beautiful, strong, and fast.

an3.96:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi aṅgehi samannāgato rañño bhadro assājānīyo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅganteva saṅkhyaṃ gacchati.
an3.96:1.4.eng: A fine royal thoroughbred with these three factors is worthy of a king. …

an3.96:1.5.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an3.96:1.5.eng: In the same way, a mendicant with three qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

an3.96:1.7.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vaṇṇasampanno ca hoti balasampanno ca javasampanno ca.
an3.96:1.7.eng: It’s when a mendicant is beautiful, strong, and fast.

an3.96:2.1.eng: And how is a mendicant beautiful?

an3.96:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
an3.96:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an3.96:2.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vaṇṇasampanno hoti.
an3.96:2.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is beautiful.

an3.96:3.1.eng: And how is a mendicant strong?

an3.96:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.
an3.96:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They are strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

an3.96:3.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu balasampanno hoti.
an3.96:3.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is strong.

an3.96:4.1.eng: And how is a mendicant fast?

an3.96:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti;
an3.96:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ …

an3.96:4.5.eng: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

an3.96:4.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu javasampanno hoti.
an3.96:4.6.eng: That’s how a mendicant is fast.

an3.96:4.7.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā”ti.
an3.96:4.7.eng: A mendicant with these three qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.”

an3.97:4.1.eng: And how is a mendicant fast?

an3.97:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
an3.97:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, with the ending of the five lower fetters, is reborn spontaneously. They’re extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world.

an3.97:4.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu javasampanno hoti.
an3.97:4.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is fast.

an3.97:4.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā”ti.

an3.99:1.1.pli: “Navopi, bhikkhave, potthako dubbaṇṇo ca hoti dukkhasamphasso ca appaggho ca;
an3.99:1.1.eng: “Jute canvas is ugly, unpleasant to touch, and worthless whether it’s new, worn in, or worn out.

an3.99:1.2.pli: majjhimopi, bhikkhave, potthako dubbaṇṇo ca hoti dukkhasamphasso ca appaggho ca;

an3.99:1.3.pli: jiṇṇopi, bhikkhave, potthako dubbaṇṇo ca hoti dukkhasamphasso ca appaggho ca.

an3.99:1.4.pli: Jiṇṇampi, bhikkhave, potthakaṃ ukkhaliparimajjanaṃ vā karonti saṅkārakūṭe vā naṃ chaḍḍenti.
an3.99:1.4.eng: They use worn out jute canvas for scrubbing cauldrons, or else they just throw it away on the rubbish heap.

an3.99:2.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, navo cepi bhikkhu hoti dussīlo pāpadhammo.
an3.99:2.1.eng: In the same way, if a junior mendicant is unethical, of bad character,

an3.99:2.2.eng: this is how they’re ugly, I say.

an3.99:2.3.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, potthako dubbaṇṇo tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ puggalaṃ vadāmi.
an3.99:2.3.eng: That individual is just as ugly as jute canvas.

an3.99:2.4.pli: Ye kho panassa sevanti bhajanti payirupāsanti diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjanti, tesaṃ taṃ hoti dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya.
an3.99:2.4.eng: If you associate with, accompany, and attend to them, following their example, it’ll be for your lasting harm and suffering.

an3.99:2.5.eng: This is how they’re unpleasant to touch, I say.

an3.99:2.6.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, potthako dukkhasamphasso tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ puggalaṃ vadāmi.
an3.99:2.6.eng: That individual is just as unpleasant to touch as jute canvas.

an3.99:2.7.pli: Yesaṃ kho pana so paṭiggaṇhāti cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ, tesaṃ taṃ na mahapphalaṃ hoti na mahānisaṃsaṃ.
an3.99:2.7.eng: Any robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick that they receive are not very fruitful or beneficial for the donor.

an3.99:2.8.eng: This is how they’re worthless, I say.

an3.99:2.9.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, potthako appaggho tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ puggalaṃ vadāmi.
an3.99:2.9.eng: That individual is just as worthless as jute canvas.

an3.99:2.10.eng: If a middle mendicant is unethical, of bad character, this is how they’re ugly, I say. …

an3.99:2.11.pli: thero cepi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu hoti dussīlo pāpadhammo, idamassa dubbaṇṇatāya vadāmi.
an3.99:2.11.eng: If a senior mendicant is unethical, of bad character, this is how they’re ugly, I say. …

an3.99:2.12.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, potthako dubbaṇṇo tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ puggalaṃ vadāmi.

an3.99:2.13.pli: Ye kho panassa sevanti bhajanti payirupāsanti diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjanti, tesaṃ taṃ hoti dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya.
an3.99:2.13.eng: If you associate with, accompany, and attend to them, following their example, it’ll be for your lasting harm and suffering. …

an3.99:2.15.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, potthako dukkhasamphasso tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ puggalaṃ vadāmi.

an3.99:2.16.pli: Yesaṃ kho pana so paṭiggaṇhāti cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ, tesaṃ taṃ na mahapphalaṃ hoti na mahānisaṃsaṃ.

an3.99:2.18.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, potthako appaggho tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ puggalaṃ vadāmi.

an3.99:3.1.pli: Evarūpo cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, thero bhikkhu saṅghamajjhe bhaṇati.
an3.99:3.1.eng: If such a senior mendicant speaks among the Saṅgha,

an3.99:3.3.pli: ‘kiṃ nu kho tuyhaṃ bālassa abyattassa bhaṇitena,
an3.99:3.3.eng: ‘What’s an incompetent fool like you got to say?

an3.99:3.4.eng: How on earth could you imagine you’ve got something worth saying!’

an3.99:3.5.pli: So kupito anattamano tathārūpiṃ vācaṃ nicchāreti yathārūpāya vācāya saṅgho taṃ ukkhipati, saṅkārakūṭeva naṃ potthakaṃ.
an3.99:3.5.eng: They become angry and upset, and blurt out things that make the Saṅgha throw them out, as if they were throwing jute canvas away on the rubbish heap.

an3.99:4.1.pli: Navampi, bhikkhave, kāsikaṃ vatthaṃ vaṇṇavantañceva hoti sukhasamphassañca mahagghañca; majjhimampi, bhikkhave, kāsikaṃ vatthaṃ vaṇṇavantañceva hoti sukhasamphassañca mahagghañca; jiṇṇampi, bhikkhave, kāsikaṃ vatthaṃ vaṇṇavantañceva hoti sukhasamphassañca mahagghañca.
an3.99:4.1.eng: Cloth from Kāsi is beautiful, pleasant to touch, and valuable whether it’s new, worn in, or worn out.

an3.99:4.2.pli: Jiṇṇampi, bhikkhave, kāsikaṃ vatthaṃ ratanapaliveṭhanaṃ vā karoti gandhakaraṇḍake vā naṃ pakkhipanti.
an3.99:4.2.eng: They use worn out cloth from Kāsi for wrapping, or else they place it in a fragrant casket.

an3.99:5.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, navo cepi bhikkhu hoti sīlavā kalyāṇadhammo, idamassa suvaṇṇatāya vadāmi.
an3.99:5.1.eng: In the same way, if a junior mendicant is ethical, of good character, this is how they’re beautiful, I say.

an3.99:5.2.pli: Seyyathāpi taṃ, bhikkhave, kāsikaṃ vatthaṃ vaṇṇavantaṃ tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ puggalaṃ vadāmi.
an3.99:5.2.eng: That individual is just as beautiful as cloth from Kāsi.

an3.99:5.3.pli: Ye kho panassa sevanti bhajanti payirupāsanti diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjanti, tesaṃ taṃ hoti dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya.
an3.99:5.3.eng: If you associate with, accompany, and attend to such an individual, following their example, it will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.

an3.99:5.4.eng: This is how they’re pleasant to touch, I say.

an3.99:5.5.pli: Seyyathāpi taṃ, bhikkhave, kāsikaṃ vatthaṃ sukhasamphassaṃ tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ puggalaṃ vadāmi.
an3.99:5.5.eng: That individual is just as pleasant to touch as cloth from Kāsi.

an3.99:5.6.pli: Yesaṃ kho pana so paṭiggaṇhāti cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ, tesaṃ taṃ mahapphalaṃ hoti mahānisaṃsaṃ.
an3.99:5.6.eng: Any robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick that they receive are very fruitful and beneficial for the donor.

an3.99:5.7.eng: This is how they’re valuable, I say.

an3.99:5.8.pli: Seyyathāpi taṃ, bhikkhave, kāsikaṃ vatthaṃ mahagghaṃ tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ puggalaṃ vadāmi.
an3.99:5.8.eng: That individual is just as valuable as cloth from Kāsi.

an3.99:5.9.eng: If a middle mendicant is ethical, of good character, this is how they’re beautiful, I say. …

an3.99:5.10.pli: thero cepi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu hoti …pe… puggalaṃ vadāmi.
an3.99:5.10.eng: If a senior mendicant is ethical, of good character, this is how they’re beautiful, I say. …

an3.99:6.1.pli: Evarūpo cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, thero bhikkhu saṅghamajjhe bhaṇati.
an3.99:6.1.eng: If such a senior mendicant speaks in the midst of the Saṅgha,

an3.99:6.3.pli: ‘appasaddā āyasmanto hotha, thero bhikkhu dhammañca vinayañca bhaṇatī’ti.
an3.99:6.3.eng: ‘Venerables, be quiet! The senior mendicant is speaking on the teaching and training.’

an3.99:6.4.eng: So you should train like this:

an3.99:6.5.eng: ‘We will be like cloth from Kāsi, not like jute canvas.’
